Filter bubbles can harm democracy and we.title: Filter Bubbles vs. Democracy in the Age of Social Media
content: Filter Bubbles vs. Democracy in the Age of Social Media

Mariah Brenders Follow Social Media Filter Bubbles -- Listen Share December 5, 2017 Since their debut, social media platforms in westernized societies have been changing the way users connect and interact with each other.
A “platform”, as explained by José van Dijck, has multiple roles.

It is a mediator that “shapes the performance of social acts,” a provider of services that code social activity with algorithms and protocols to be displayed in “user-friendly interfaces,” and can figuratively act as a “political [stage] and performative infrastructure” (van Dijck 29).
Facebook, for example, epitomizes all of these aspects.
Their user-friendly website acts as a mediator for social activities and discussion, and it is often used by individuals or parties to express their political views.

Since platforms “are a newly predominant type of business model premised upon bringing different groups together” (Srnicek 254), then Facebook can be said to partake in platform capitalism — a system of capitalism involving the commoditization of users and social production.

User data, harvested with the help of coded platform architecture such as algorithms and protocols, is the main commodity sold by platforms. Facebook platform architecture results in a phenomenon that Eli Pariser terms ‘the filter bubble’.
The filter bubble is unavoidable and personalized;
it occurs when an individual is surrounded only by things that they want to see (Pariser 9).

This trend makes it challenging for radical partisans in a democratic society to be exposed to, let alone understand, each others’ opinions, and may contribute to unexpected political changes, such as ‘Brexit’ in the UK.

Filter bubbles, formed as a result of algorithms on social media websites such as Facebook, have diminished the exchange of opposing viewpoints necessary for a healthy, functioning democracy, and in some cases have subsequently led to radical political change.
Platform capitalism is organized around the “centrality of data” (Srnicek 254) and the profitability of that data for the platform business model.
Facebook generates revenue by acting as a medium between advertisers and consumers, and controlling the means of social cooperation and commodity production (Sevignani 61).
By collecting user data through its platform, Facebook is able to commodify social interactions and sell them to third-party companies.
The results of this data analysis are shown on the social media platform in “targeted advertisements and recommendations appearing as banners or running in sidebars” (Langley & Leyshon 12).
For example, if a user once ‘liked’ a Facebook page about gardening, they may see targeted advertisements for gardening tools.
A gardening company would have paid Facebook to showcase their advertisement on this user’s screen because the advertisement may attract the user, who likes to garden, to the third-party website.
In this example, Facebook is making money by providing the targeted user/potential consumer to the marketer;
Facebook uses data collection to convert their users into commodities.
A platform’s architecture is crucial to the extraction of meaningful data.

Srnicek asserts that “by providing the infrastructure and intermediation between different groups, platforms place themselves in a position in which they can monitor and extract all the interactions between these groups” (254–55).
Facebook provides a social media platform through which users can connect, but its interface constantly monitors and shapes these interactions.
This shaping is done with the use of social algorithms and protocols.
One of Facebook’s first algorithms was the ‘like’ button, “a feature that lets users express their instant approval of a specific idea or item and share it” (van Dijck 49).
Every time a user ‘likes’ something on Facebook, that information is stored according to protocols that categorize this data to be later used to create targeted advertisements.

In 2016, Facebook debuted ‘reactions,’ which are similar to the ‘like’ feature, but let users choose from a range of emotional reactions, such as the ‘love’, ‘sad’, or ‘angry’ reactions, to items on the platform (Krug 2016).

This development supports Facebook’s capitalist agenda, as it helps them to collect increasingly specific data about a user’s feelings on particular content, thereby gaining the power to promise third-party marketers interested viewers for their paid advertisements.
Social buttons not only encourage interaction among users on social media, but act as a further source for data collection from which Facebook can profit.
Underlying the social button feature are additional algorithms and protocols that influence a user to ‘like’ content in the first place.
These algorithms are what control the platform’s unique appearance for each person.
Facebook’s proprietary algorithms, EdgeRank and GraphRank, “filter data produced by users and shape them into a meaningful stream of information for that specific user” (van Dijck 49).
EdgeRank analyzes each user’s interactions with their friends and ranks that person’s connections in order of importance (49).
The people whom it deems most important to a user are the ones who will show up first on the user’s newsfeed.
Over time, EdgeRank has become more of a general term that applies to the personalized optimization of each individual’s newsfeed (Greenstein).
GraphRank, on the other hand, is an algorithm that ranks Open Graph application activity based on a user’s interactions with specific apps.
The Open Graph feature allows third-party companies to advertise to consumers who have previously expressed interest in similar applications (Darwell).
These algorithms exemplify Facebook’s control over what users see on social media.
They expose people to an incredibly personalized rather than general selection of content.
Facebook therefore influences social activity by placing priorities on what and whom its users see and have the opportunity to interact with.
At first glance, the effects of social media algorithms appear to be beneficial both to users and to Facebook.
Who would not want to be solely immersed in content they enjoy?
This type of environment is what Pariser calls the filter bubble.

As previously mentioned, the filter bubble exists when individuals are surrounded only by content that they have expressed an interest in, content that has been curated for them by automated algorithms. The algorithms are based on personal choices that a user has made, from pages they have liked to friends they associate with (Lazer).
These choices are reinforced by algorithms to the point that users are only exposed to specific people and content.
It is a very individualizing experience and can result in the diminution of the public discussion that is essential to a functioning democracy.
Pariser explains that “in a personalized world, important but complex issues .
are less likely to come to our attention at all” (Pariser 18) because public matters are often excluded from people’s niches and self-interests (17).
As a result, Facebook users’ experiences online are biased towards their own points of view, and supported by the content they are exposed to according to Facebook’s platform architecture.
They often live in misunderstanding of important public topics of debate and instead occupy their minds with material they find positive and unchallenging.
Democracy is threatened by filter bubbles because they hinder social media users’ participation in the online public sphere and manipulate their understanding of reality.
According to Jürgen Habermas, the public sphere was originally a place for “overcoming private interests and opinions to discover common interests and to reach societal consensus” (Kellner 20).

However, large media corporations are increasingly gaining power over the private realm, thereby leading to a shift to in focus from rational public debate over the common good to private group interests (22).
Filter bubbles have contributed to the decrease in public debate online in democratic societies because they surround individuals with information relating to their own private interests.

Eli Pariser argues that “living inside [the bubble], we may miss some of the mental flexibility and openness that contact with difference creates” (Pariser 101), therefore leading to an inability to understand opposing points of view which are critical for rational debate in the public sphere.
These undemocratic filter bubbles produce individuals who are governed by confirmation bias.
Confirmation bias occurs when information an individual is exposed to only reaffirms their existing beliefs.
Facebook’s coded architecture, for instance, personalizes content to each individual’s interests, thereby reaffirming their point of view in the things they see.
Social media algorithms can thus contribute to strengthening private interests and reducing the participation of rational debate online in democratic societies.

There is a strong counterargument to the claim that filter bubbles are decreasing users’ participation in rational democratic debates online, and it asserts that the public sphere is different from the one which Habermas originally described.
Multiple critics of Habermas have pointed out the exclusion of minority groups in his outdated concept of the bourgeois public sphere, “dominated by white, property-owning males” (Kellner 24).
Douglas Kellner, for instance, acknowledges social networking platforms as an updated and more inclusive public sphere in which there is equal participation and debate amongst social groups (37).
He believes this new sphere has “the potential both to invigorate democracy and to increase the dissemination of critical and progressive ideas” (37).

While it is true that there is potential to invigorate democracy, this potential is blocked by the architecture of these platforms. For example, it has been proven that social media was essential to spreading information about the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement and police brutality (Freelon et al.)
Facebook gave voice to a minority group in the public sphere — a group who otherwise is not represented by Habermas’s ‘white male’ concept.
But how far did that voice actually reach?
Personalized algorithms on the platform would not have shown information about the BLM movement to, say, radical right-wing conservatives and/or Ku Klux Klan members.
How then, can critics like Kellner claim that social media is encouraging democratic debate and the spread of progressive ideologies between social groups with opposing viewpoints?
There cannot be equal participation and debate if the groups are polarized by the filter bubbles in which they live.
Although Facebook is idealized as a platform of equal participation, public deliberation and dissemination of progressive ideas online are inhibited by the constraints of filter bubbles.
Filter bubbles’ individualizing effects and the resulting confirmation bias can contribute to unexpected political change in democratic societies.
These changes are ‘unexpected’ by opposing ideological groups because, as Pariser explains, “partisans of one political stripe tend not to consume the media of another” (Pariser 88).
This claim is reinforced by the reactions of some political groups to the results of the ‘Brexit’ referendum in June 2016.
Many left-wing supporters and mainstream news agencies were shocked by the outcome of these polls (Jackson;
Shoebridge).
These unexpected results could have been predicted had there been a more open public discussion and bridging between ideological social groups online.
Alternative opinions did not infiltrate left-wing filter bubbles because their personal choices and the resulting algorithms had surrounded them with content that supported their ideologies.

In fact, an analytical study done on Facebook page engagement around the term “European Union” during the month of the Brexit referendum revealed an overwhelming popularity of pro-‘Leave’ related pages compared to pro-‘Remain’ associated pages (Herrman).
The ‘Leave’ campaign capitalized on individuals with populist ideals who turned to their filter bubbles to find like-minded opinions.
They reached out to them on social media “using very simple language, largely consisting of only a few syllables .
[which] were often reinforced with amusing memes” (Polonski).
This simplistic but extensive technique subtly reinforced pro-Brexit voters’ previously held beliefs by using confirmation bias.
In this case, social media filter bubbles were used as a tool to influence voter sentiment.
The capitalization of Facebook filter bubbles reintroduces the topic of capitalism, and the power of a platform to influence its users.

A division of the data analytics firm Cambridge Analytica was one of the major campaign budget expenses for Vote Leave (official ‘Leave’ campaign), BeLeave, Veterans for Britain, and the Democratic Unionist Party (Cadwalladr).
This firm used voter demographics data to skew the Brexit referendum results in the favour of the ‘Leave’ campaign.
Carol Cadwalladr, investigative journalist for The Guardian, discovered that “Facebook was the source of the psychological insights that enabled Cambridge Analytica to target individuals.
It was also the mechanism that enabled them to be delivered on a large scale” (Cadwalladr).
This important revelation intricately links social media and political capitalism.

User data was harvested by Facebook, who sold it to Cambridge Analytica, who sold it to ‘Leave’ campaigns, who then created targeted advertisements to be shown to persuadable users, who were singled out with the help of Facebook algorithms and filter bubbles.
This entire process relies on the fact that Facebook promises to deliver influenceable individuals to the marketers.

Facebook essentially capitalizes on filter bubbles because it knows that users within certain ideological bubbles will be more persuadable than others, and it can promise this fact to advertisers in order to increase revenue.
The Brexit referendum is therefore exposed as — at least partially — a product of platform capitalism.
To conclude, social media filter bubbles are isolating environments constructed by architectural algorithms and protocols that can lead to highly polarized online communities.
It is important to keep in mind the capitalist intent underlying the structures of social media platforms such as Facebook.
These invisible forces are manifested in the targeted advertisements users see that attempt to manipulate their consumerist — and oftentimes political — choices.
Users must remember to question the information that is provided to them online, as it is often catered toward a biased interest.

They should challenge themselves to seek out “a diversity of ideas” (Pariser 101) that is not immediately offered within their sculpted bubbles to be able to fully participate in rational debate that is their right as a citizen in a democratic society.
The internet was originally envisioned as an equal playing field for all individuals, yet capitalist interests have still found a way to commodify the user experience.

These bubbles create higher levels of engagement, but come with pitfalls— including limiting people’s exposure to diverse views and driving polarization among friends, families and colleagues.
This effect isn’t a coincidence either.
Rather, it’s directly related to the profit-maximizing algorithms used by social media and tech giants on platforms like Twitter, Facebook, TikTok and YouTube.
In a refreshing twist, one team of researchers in Finland and Denmark has a different vision for how social media platforms could work.
They developed a new algorithm that increases the diversity of exposure on social networks, while still ensuring that content is widely shared.
Antonis Matakos, a PhD student in the Computer Science Department at Aalto University in Espoo, Finland, helped develop the new algorithm.
He expresses concern about the social media algorithms being used now.
While current algorithms mean that people more often encounter news stories and information that they enjoy, the effect can decrease a person’s exposure to diverse opinions and perspectives.
“Eventually, people tend to forget that points of view, systems of values, ways of life, other than their own exist.
Such a situation corrodes the functioning of society, and leads to polarization and conflict,” Matakos says.
“Additionally,” he says, “people might develop a distorted view of reality, which may also pave the way for the rapid spread of fake news and rumors.
” Matakos’ research is focused on reversing these harmful trends.

He and his colleagues describe their new algorithm in a study published in November in IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering The approach involves assigning numerical values to both social media content and users.
The values represent a position on an ideological spectrum, for example far left or far right.
These numbers are used to calculate a diversity exposure score for each user.
Essentially, the algorithm is identifying social media users who would share content that would lead to the maximum spread of a broad variety of news and information perspectives.

Then, diverse content is presented to a select group of people with a given diversity score who are most likely to help the content propagate across the social media network—thus maximizing the diversity scores of all users.
In their study, the researchers compare their new social media algorithm to several other models in a series of simulations.
One of these other models was a simpler method that selects the most well-connected users and recommends content that maximizes a person’s individual diversity exposure score.

Matakos says his group’s algorithm provides a feed for social media users that is at least three times more diverse (according to the researchers’ metric) than this simpler method, and even more so for baseline methods used for comparison in the study.

These results suggest that targeting a strategic group of social media users and feeding them the right content is more effective for propagating diverse views through a social media network than focusing on the most well-connected users.
Importantly, the simulations completed in the study also suggest that the new model is scalable.

A major hurdle, of course, is whether social media networks would be open to incorporating the algorithm into their systems. Matakos says that, ideally, his new algorithm could be an opt-in feature that social media networks offer to their users.
“I think [the social networks] would be potentially open to the idea,” says Matakos.
“However, in practice we know that the social network algorithms that generate users' news feeds are orientated towards maximizing profit, so it would need to be a big step away from that direction.

This leaves users’ newsfeed vulnerable to misinformation and might not provide them with a view of the full spectrum of news.
There is research on the reaction of users confronted with filter bubbles and tools to avoid them, but it is not much known about the users’ awareness of the phenomenon.
We conducted a survey about the usage of Facebook’s newsfeed with 140 participants from Germany and identified two user groups with k-means clustering.

One group consisting of passive Facebook users was not very aware of the issue, while users of the other group, mainly heavy professional Facebook users were more aware and more inclined to apply avoidance strategies.
Especially users who were aware of filter bubbles wished for a tool to counter them.

We recommend targeting users of the first group to increase awareness and find out more about the way professionals use Facebook to assist them countering the filter bubble and promoting tools that help them do so.

A filter bubble is a term coined by the Internet activist Eli Pariser to refer to a state of intellectual isolation that can result from personalized searches when a website algorithm selectively guesses what information a user would like to see based on information about the user, such as location, past click-behavior and search history.
As a result, users become separated from information that disagrees with their viewpoints, effectively isolating them in their own cultural or ideological bubbles.

Since the content seen by individual social media users is influenced by algorithms that produce filter bubbles, users of social media platforms are more susceptible to confirmation bias and may be exposed to biased, misleading information.
